title: 110_hr6560
content: The Earned Import Allowance Program is added to the Dominican Republic-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows eligible apparel articles from eligible countries to enter the US duty-free, regardless of fabric source, with an import allowance certificate reflecting fabric credits. Conversion factors from the US Department of Commerce apply for determining fabric equivalents. The program is established under the Secretary of Commerce. The Earned Import Allowance Program, established by the Secretary of Commerce, provides import allowance certificates to producers in eligible countries based on fabric credits. Producers earn one credit for every two square meter equivalents of qualifying fabric purchased for manufacturing eligible apparel articles. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows producers in eligible countries to earn credits by purchasing qualifying fabric for manufacturing. These credits can be redeemed for import allowance certificates. Textile mills in the US exporting qualifying fabric to eligible countries can submit documentation to the Secretary of Commerce. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows US textile mills to submit documentation to the Secretary of Commerce verifying the export of qualifying fabric to eligible countries. The Secretary of Commerce may require producers or entities in eligible countries to submit documentation to verify purchases of qualifying fabric. The Secretary of Commerce may provide information from submitted documentation related to qualifying fabric purchases. The program allows electronic submission, storage, retrieval, and reconciliation of information. Procedures will be established to carry out the program. The Secretary of Commerce will establish procedures by September 30, 2008, for a program related to qualifying fabric purchases. The program includes electronic submission, storage, retrieval, and reconciliation of information. Definitions for terms like 'appropriate congressional committees', 'eligible apparel articles', 'eligible country', and 'qualifying fabric' are provided. The term 'eligible country' in the context refers to the Dominican Republic. 'Qualifying fabric' is defined as woven cotton fabric wholly made in the US from US yarns suitable for apparel production. Fabric with nylon filament yarn or yarns not entirely US-made may still qualify. The Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act allows fabric with up to 10 percent non-US yarns to still qualify as eligible fabric. Additionally, fabric with designated non-commercially available yarns or fibers is not disqualified. The text outlines various provisions from different trade agreements and acts that determine the eligibility of textile or apparel articles for preferential treatment. This includes specific sections from agreements such as the North American Free Trade Agreement, the African Growth and Opportunity Act, the Andean Trade Preference Act, and the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act. The United States International Trade Commission conducts an annual review of a program for evaluating its effectiveness and making recommendations for improvements. A report on the review results is submitted to congressional committees. The program is effective for a 10-year period after the President certifies certain sections of a Presidential Proclamation have taken effect. The program for evaluating effectiveness is in effect for 10 years after the President certifies specific sections of a Presidential Proclamation have taken effect. It applies to qualifying fabric exported to eligible countries after August 1, 2007. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents for the Dominican Republic-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The African Growth and Opportunity Act includes the Earned Import Allowance Program. The African Growth and Opportunity Act is amended to define a "lesser developed beneficiary sub-Saharan African country" as one with a per capita gross national product of less than $1,500 in 1998. The African Growth and Opportunity Act is amended to include Botswana, Namibia, and Mauritius as beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries with a per capita gross national product of less than $1,500 in 1998. The United States International Trade Commission will review and report on textile and apparel inputs that can be produced competitively in these countries through new investments or measures. The United States International Trade Commission will submit a report on the review of textile and apparel inputs that can be competitively produced in beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries. The Comptroller General will then provide recommendations for changes to trade preference programs, including the African Growth and Opportunity Act, to enhance investment and competitiveness. The African Growth and Opportunity Act and other trade preference programs aim to boost investment and competitiveness in sub-Saharan African countries for textile and apparel production. Definitions for congressional committees and beneficiary countries are provided. A clerical amendment is made to Public Law 109-432. The term "countries" is defined in the Trade Act of 1974. A clerical amendment is made to Public Law 109-432. SEC. 3. Generalized System of Preferences amended to extend deadline to December 31, 2009. SEC. 4. Customs user fees deadlines amended to January 31, 2018. Repeal of sections in the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008. SEC. 5. Increase in corporate estimated tax percentage by 1.75 points. SEC. 6. Technical corrections made. The Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 is amended to increase the percentage by 1.75 points. Technical corrections are made to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008.
